Seeing as this board seems to be filled with disgruntled ex-BKSY investors who bought the stock way too high, and too early, and then sold, realizing a cap gains loss, here’s my objective take on the company:

BKSY announce they’re issuing 10 million new shares of stock (+/-15% of float). What happens next? BKSY drops 50% on the news.

This by itself doesn’t make any sense. The math doesn’t support the 50% drop on a 15% share dilution. By itself this is a massive overreaction.

But when you add the $46m they made on the offering AND the 2 new contacts signed since then… The math is not in favor of the bears here.

Buying every share under $6 I can.  BKSY $8/share all day. $12 in a potential buyout ever up.

uhhhh.... you're joking right? Over 100 million dollers in debt and they lost over 50 million dollars last year. They only have 25 million in cash currently, and if they raise 30 or 40 million with this latest round of dilution then their cash will only last them a little over a year before they're bankrupt. They wont be able to raise much capital after this because the stock price is so beat up and already diluted half to death and they wont be able to take out much new debt because of their bad financial position. Make no mistake, this is a bankrupcy or buyout play. This company is on thin ice. This is all just my opinion though, but something tells me I wont be proven wrong

You have to finance growth and assuming the offering goes well they will be cashed up to grow the business, beautiful entry point for those that have been waiting for this financing to inflict its temporary pain.

I just think the company hit us with both barrels. First, the reverse split. Second, further dilution with additional shares. Could they not have done one, or the other? Not both? I’ve lost faith the stock holders are considered in management’s decisions/planning.

After long consideration I think I'll pass on this company. that much dilution at this low of a stock price is scary. It would be one thing if this was the last round of dilution and the company was nearly at profitability from now on. However their losses are massive relative to their revenue, and arent projected to turn a profit for multiple years so there will be further dilution down the road even after this. These are just my personal views though, and I hope I'm wrong for the sake of the people still in this stock

I do not see open market buys.....I do see compensation based awards of options in early Sept. There is a difference between open market buys and compensation awards.  But there were indeed 135,135 shares awarded to six directors.

Where exactly do you see this? I see literally zero filings (or other reports) to suggest that insiders have outright purchased this stock at any time since it's gone public. Insiders at the company are awarded stock grants periodically as part of their compensation. Perhaps you are confused. 811K shares this month alone sounds about right for those stock grants. It's true they haven't yet filed to sell any of those recent shares they were awarded. But that's a far cry from them actually "purchasing" the shares. I'm not bearish on this company fundamentally. I really don't know what their capable of in terms of revenues, earnings, investor interest, etc... going forward. But clearly the stock remains in a major downtrend for the time being. And I see zero evidence that any significant accumulation is going on be it by insiders, institutions, or retail investors. So far, mostly just ongoing distribution since the SPAC went public.

RS only relevant to investor sentiment. Clearly worsens sentiment. Sentiment was already terrible. Now we'll see how bad it can get. Based on market cap (ultimately more relevant stat than stock price), investors have little faith in this company's business model, short term mid term or long term. And that's been the case for a LONG time. I have no idea where the bottom is for SP or market cap. But if revenue and margin trends continue and management is to be believed (questionable given how they marketed the SPAC), profitability is not actually very far away for this company. And then things could "rocket" from there. But in the meantime, stock price will languish (RS or not) until the company show's an actual profit and it becomes crystal clear that further dilution is unnecessary. Also need better visibility into EV/ ROI of the capital investments and sustainability of business model overall.  I have no deep understanding of their competitive position within their industry but they seem like they've gotten long term contracts so revenues should be relatively stable at least for the next few years. Fact is, company could have diluted with or with out the RS. On the plus side, mrq and 12 month trailing free cash flow is "not that bad" relative to their cash position and revenue growth so MAYBE they can avoid further dilution. And so maybe the bottom is near. Maybe.

from the proxy statement filed on July 25 reguarding the Reverse split... among others it states as a reson for the reverse split : "Our board of directors believes it is in the best interests of the Company and our stockholders to increase our number of authorized shares of common stock available for future issuance in order to have additional shares available for use as our board of directors deems appropriate or necessary. The Reverse Stock Split will provide the Company with greater flexibility with respect to managing its common stock in connection with such corporate purposes as may, from time to time, be considered advisable by our board of directors. These corporate purposes could include, without limitation, financing activities, public or private offerings of common stock, issuance of equity awards pursuant to our equity compensation plans, and strategic business development transactions."
